intro: Carex lacustris var. laxiflora, commonly known as the slender-flowered marsh sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and clustered, spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in shallow water or damp soil, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, with male and female flowers often occurring on separate spikes. This variety is distinguished by its more loosely arranged flowers compared to other Carex species.
